data.sampled: xeb. The recessive allele is present in all the offsprings produced from the heterozygous parents (xeB/XeB). This means that when the two heterozygotes are crossed, they both express the dominant allele, giving us an F1 generation of XeB/XeB individuals. However, since these individuals have two copies of the recessive allele, they will show the recessive phenotype when bred together. Thus, the allele in the middle must be xeb.

data.sampled:
uj.

The answer is "ujs" because this is the only combination that produces an even number of offspring (538+73+68+59+71+530+59+66=2434). In a three-point test cross, if two parental alleles are heterozygous at one locus and their recombinant gametes fuse to form a zygote, the resulting F1 generation will have a phenotypic ratio of 1:2:1, meaning that one-fourth of the offspring will show the dominant trait, one-half will show the recessive trait, and one-fourth will be intermediate. This can only happen if there has been a crossing over event between the alleles during meiosis, which results in a new combination of alleles in the offspring. Therefore, if we get an even number of offspring in a three-point test cross, it means that there was no crossing over between the alleles and they remained together in the offspring. Thus, the allele in the middle is the one that produced an even number of offspring, which in this case is "ujs".

data.sampled:
hog.

To explain: In a three-point testcross, we are given the phenotypes of the heterozygous parent (het) and its two reciprocal hemizygous parents (hom). The goal is to determine which alleles the het parent possesses. By observing the resulting phenotypes of the F1 generation from crossing the het parent with one hom parent and then backcrossing those F1 individuals to the other hom parent, we can infer the presence/absence of certain alleles at that locus. If the het parent has an " dominant" allele, it will always show up as such regardless of whether it's homozygous or heterozygous. Similarly, if the het parent has a "recessive" allele, it too will always show up as such. However, if neither dominance relationship holds between the two alleles, then we must observe the results of the testcross to determine their relationships.
In this case, since the numbers of the different phenotypes observed do not follow any simple Mendelian pattern, we cannot immediately determine whether either of these alleles is dominant or recessive over the other. Nonetheless, based on our observations of the resulting phenotypes across all six possible matings, we know that there are two different alleles present - hoG and hog - and that they appear to segregate in a 3:1 ratio. We therefore conclude that these two alleles are codominant. Since the central column represents the het parent, the allele that appears most frequently among the F1 generation is the codominant allele, so we select that as our answer. Therefore, the allele in the middle is hog.

data.sampled:
tir.
The allele "tir" is found in the middle of this test cross. The numbers on either side are due to mutations (random variations) which lead to different phenotypes or traits, while the original parental alleles remain unchanged. In this case, both Tir and tIR are dominant over tir and tiR. However, TiR is also dominant but not as strong as Tir, so it has fewer offspring than Tir. While tIr is recessive, it still produces some offspring because there are two copies of it present (heterozygous). Finally, tir itself has no dominance effects, so its frequency remains relatively constant throughout the generations.

In summary, the gene expression for this example would be:

T - Tir > TiR > tIr > tir < tiR < T.
This means that Tir is most expressed, followed by TiR, then tIr, tir in the center, and finally tiR least expressed. The dominant alleles produce more offspring than their recessive counterparts, which explains why they have higher frequencies overall. But note that the exact ratios will depend on many factors such as population size, selection pressures, random drift, migration, etc. So these results may differ from other populations or under different conditions. Nevertheless, this type of analysis can help us understand how genes interact and influence trait variation within a species, and thus contribute to evolutionary processes like adaptation, speciation, and biodiversity.

data.sampled:
nut.

Explanation: The capital "N" represents dominant alleles while the lowercase "n" represents recessive alleles. In this case, we are looking for the allele in the middle which is the heterozygous state where both dominant and recessive alleles are present. Since the third parent has two copies of the same allele (either NuT or nUt), it can either donate one copy to form a heterozygote or not donate any at all. Therefore, there could be three possible outcomes - nUt, nuT and Nut. From the given data, we can see that there were more offspring with heterozygotes having nUt allele than other two possibilities put together. Hence, nUt is the most likely allele in the middle position. However, since we cannot completely rule out the possibility of homozygosity at either extreme positions, we should report our answer as "nUt". If further information is available such as molecular analysis or sequencing results, then we may change our conclusion accordingly.
